title: News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election | 49.4% Respondents Say People Won't Find It Difficult To Differentiate Between National, State Parties
summary: As per the survey, 49.4 per cent of the respondents feel that voters will not face problems in differentiating between candidates and parties at national and state levels compared to 39.1 per cent feeling otherwise.
full_content: News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election | 49.4% Respondents Say People Won't Find It Difficult To Differentiate Between National, State Parties Curated By : News Desk News18.com Last Updated: January 08, 2025, 16:25 IST As per the survey, 49.4 per cent of the respondents feel that voters will not face problems in differentiating between candidates and parties at national and state levels compared to 39.1 per cent feeling otherwise. reset Follow us on Google News Voters stand in queue  | Image/PTI (File) With One Nation One Election Bill with the Joint Parliamentary Committee, several questions around how one election will impact people are being asked. One of these is whether voters will face problems in differentiating between candidates and parties at national and state levels with simultaneous polls. According to a News18 Pulse survey, nearly 50 per cent respondents expressed confidence that there will be no confusion. As per the survey, 49.4 per cent of the respondents feel that voters will not face problems in differentiating between candidates and parties at national and state levels compared to 39.1 per cent feeling otherwise. More respondents in South (46 per cent) and West (46.6 per cent) think that voters will face problems in differentiating between candidates and parties at national and state levels. related stories Even among respondents who support the ONOE proposal, about one thirds, 33.6 per cent of respondents feel that voters will face problems in differentiating between candidates and parties at national and state levels. However, 55.9 per cent respondents in Central India, 62 per cent in East, 52 per cent in North and 44.7 per cent in North East say that confusion over local and national candidates will not prevail when ONOE comes into effect. According to the survey, the ONOE proposal is witnessing 80.1 per cent backing from across the country. The support for ONOE is especially strong in Central, East, and North regions while it is relatively lower in the South, West and North East. News18 conducted an India-wide survey on ONOP. A total of 4,573 respondents were interviewed between December 23 and December 31, 2024, across 29 states and UTs of India. Out of those interviewed, 86.5 per cent were Hindus. While 66.1 per cent were urban respondents, 33.9 per cent were rural. Meanwhile, 73.7 per cent surveyed were males while 26.3 per cent were females. top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all The Constitution (129th Amendment) Bill and the Union Territories Laws (Amendment) Bill were introduced in the Lok Sabha during the Winter Session and referred to the JPC. The 39-member JPC is headed by BJP MP and former minister of state for law, PP Chaudhary. The panel also includes Priyanka Gandhi Vadra of the Congress, Sanjay Jha of the JD(U), Shiv Sena’s Shrikant Shinde, AAP’s Sanjay Singh, and TMC’s Kalyan Banerjee. tags : News18 Pulse ONOP One Nation One Poll One Nation-One Election Location : New Delhi, India First Published: January 08, 2025, 13:00 IST News elections News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election | 49.4% Respondents Say People Won't Find It Difficult To Differentiate Between National, State Parties Read More

title: News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election | 80% Respondents Feel ONOE Will Make Day-To-Day Life Easier
summary: While 90 per cent people in North India believe One Nation One Election will make day to day life easy, at least 24.4 per cent in South India feel that may not be the case, as per the News18 survey.
full_content: News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election | 80% Respondents Feel ONOE Will Make Day-To-Day Life Easier Curated By : News Desk News18.com Last Updated: January 08, 2025, 16:16 IST While 90 per cent people in North India believe One Nation One Election will make day to day life easy, at least 24.4 per cent in South India feel that may not be the case, as per the News18 survey. reset Follow us on Google News With elections once in 5 years, a majority of people believe this will reduce disruptions to day-to-day life. (Image: PTI/File) The One Nation One Election Bill is with the Joint Parliamentary Committee (JPC) which met for the first time on Wednesday after the legislation was introduced in Parliament. According to News18 Pulse, over 80 per cent people surveyed believe that having fewer elections can ease daily life with lesser disruptions. It has been observed how every time elections take place, rallies lead to traffic woes for locals and schools and offices are shut for a couple of days for polling. However, with elections once in 5 years, a majority of people believe this will reduce disruptions to day-to-day life. related stories While 90 per cent people in North India believe One Nation One Election will make day to day life easy, at least 24.4 per cent in South India feel that may not be the case, as per the News18 survey. The ONOE Bill has gotten thumbs up for making daily life easy from 87.4 per cent people in Central India, 85.4 per cent in East India, 90 per cent in North India, 90 per cent in North India, 78.1 per cent from North East India, 67.5 per cent in South India and 72.6 per cent in West India. Overall, only 13.2 per cent people say that ONOE will lead to lesser disruptions in day to day life while 6 per cent said they were not sure whether or not that may happen. News18 conducted an India-wide survey on ONOP between December 23 and December 31, 2024. A total of 4,573 respondents were interviewed across 29 states and UTs of India. Out of those interviewed, 86.5 per cent were Hindus. While 66.1 per cent were urban respondents, 33.9 per cent were rural. The panel also includes Priyanka Gandhi Vadra of the Congress, Sanjay Jha of the JD(U), Shiv Sena’s Shrikant Shinde, AAP’s Sanjay Singh, and TMC’s Kalyan Banerjee. tags : News18 Pulse ONOP One Nation One Poll One Nation-One Election Location : New Delhi, India First Published: January 08, 2025, 12:45 IST News elections News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election | 80% Respondents Feel ONOE Will Make Day-To-Day Life Easier Read More

title: News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election | Over 81% Respondents Feel Move Will Cut Expenditure, Save Public Money
summary: The survey also revealed that the proposal to hold simultaneous elections to the Lok Sabha and all states enjoys strong support among the country’s electorate, with 80.1 per cent backing the move
full_content: News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election | Over 81% Respondents Feel Move Will Cut Expenditure, Save Public Money Curated By : News Desk News18.com Last Updated: January 08, 2025, 12:29 IST The survey also revealed that the proposal to hold simultaneous elections to the Lok Sabha and all states enjoys strong support among the country’s electorate, with 80.1 per cent backing the move reset Follow us on Google News The One Nation, One Election proposal aims to synchronise elections for the Lok Sabha and state assemblies. A majority of India’s electorate believes that the proposal to hold simultaneous polls will reduce expenditure and save public money, a nationwide survey conducted by News18 shows. According to the survey titled ‘News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election’, 81.2% respondents are of the opinion that simultaneous polls will reduce the financial burden on the country. related stories The One Nation, One Election Bills were introduced in the Lok Sabha on December 17 last year and on Wednesday, the first meeting of the Joint Parliamentary Committee (JPC) on simultaneous polls was held. The JPC is mandated to review the Constitution (One Hundred and Twenty-Ninth Amendment) Bill, 2024, and the Union Territories Laws (Amendment) Bill, 2024, which aim to align elections at the national and state levels. It is headed by BJP MP and a former minister of state for law, PP Chaudhary, who called the meeting. The survey interviewed 4,573 respondents across 29 states and Union Territories of India. The data was collected between December 23 and December 31, 2024. Majority of those interviewed were Hindus — 86.5 per cent — followed by Muslims. Since the fieldwork was mainly restricted to cities and towns, the sample was largely urban at 66.1 per cent, barring the Northeast where a larger rural sample was surveyed. Among the respondents, while males constituted 73.7 per cent, females were at 26.3 per cent. The Northeast, however, had a more sizeable female sample. Most of the respondents fell in the 26-55 years age bracket, comprising 81.7 per cent of the respondents. The survey also revealed that the proposal to hold simultaneous elections to the Lok Sabha and all states enjoys strong support among the country’s electorate, with 80.1 per cent respondents saying they support the move. top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all Nearly 50 per cent respondents expressed confidence that voters will not face problems in differentiating between candidates and parties at national and state levels. Over half the respondents (55.9 per cent) think simultaneous voting for national and state elections will not create confusion among voters. The One Nation, One Election proposal aims to synchronise elections for the Lok Sabha and state assemblies, reducing the frequency of polls and cutting down on expenses. While its supporters argue that the move will minimise disruptions caused by frequent election cycles, the Opposition has flagged logistical challenges and the potential concentration of power. tags : lok sabha News18 Pulse ONOP One Nation-One Election Simultaneous polls Location : New Delhi, India First Published: January 08, 2025, 12:29 IST News elections News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election | Over 81% Respondents Feel Move Will Cut Expenditure, Save Public Money Read More

title: AAP, Delhi Police Clash Over Denied Entry To CM's House Amid 'Sheesh Mahal' Row
summary: The AAP leaders staged a dharna outside the CM residence in Delhi after being denied entry by the police. Sanjay Singh also had a heated exchange with the police personnel.
full_content: AAP, Delhi Police Clash Over Denied Entry To CM's House Amid 'Sheesh Mahal' Row Curated By : Ashesh Mallick News18.com Last Updated: January 08, 2025, 12:46 IST The AAP leaders staged a dharna outside the CM residence in Delhi after being denied entry by the police. Sanjay Singh also had a heated exchange with the police personnel. reset Follow us on Google News Politics heats up over 'Sheesh Mahal' in Delhi (Photo: X/BJP) As Delhi elections are hardly a month away, a massive drama unfolded on Wednesday over ‘Sheesh Mahal’, a term coined by the BJP for the Chief Minister’s residence, as AAP leaders clashed with the police after being denied entry to the premises. The AAP and BJP also sparred over the issue which is taking centre stage in the run-up to the Assembly polls in the city slated on February 5. related stories As the AAP leaders arrived at the CM residence where the Delhi Police put up barricading, besides heavy security, the police denied them entry which led to a verbal spat. AAP Dares BJP To Visit CM Residence With Media This comes after AAP MP Sanjay Singh on Tuesday challenged the BJP to visit the CM’s residence along with the media personnel, after the BJP levelled several allegations on the AAP over alleged misuse of public money in the construction of a luxurious residence for Kejriwal, the then-Delhi CM. The BJP has accused Arvind Kejriwal of spending an extravagant sum exceeding Rs 40 crore on renovating the Chief Minister’s official residence — an allegation the AAP has vehemently refuted. The AAP leaders dared the BJP to inspect the residence and substantiate their claims of excessive expenditure. AAP announced that its leaders, accompanied by the media, would visit the Civil Lines bungalow to address the allegations and then proceed to the Prime Minister’s residence at 7, Lok Kalyan Marg, to highlight the renovations carried out there. AAP Leaders Denied Entry To Delhi CM’s Residence As Delhi Minister Saurabh Bharadwaj and MP Sanjay Singh arrived at the residence, they entered into a heated exchange with police personnel deployed outside the house after being denied permission to enter the premises. “I’m an MP, he is a minister, and you’re stopping us? Under which law are you stopping us?" Singh is heard asking the police personnel. #WATCH | Delhi Minister Saurabh Bharadwaj and AAP MP Sanjay Singh enter into a heated exchange with Police personnel deployed outside the CM’s residence where a Police barricading has been put up and heavy security has been deployed. pic.twitter.com/IfmRDm9e05 — ANI (@ANI) January 8, 2025 PWD Urges Police Not To Allow Entry To CM House: Sources According to Delhi Police sources, PWD has urged the police via a letter not to allow anyone, including the AAP leaders, to enter the property. A PWD official also reached the spot and requested Sanjay Singh and Saurabh Bharadwaj not to enter the premises. Both the AAP leaders sat on a dharna for some time and then moved towards Lok Kalyan Marg. ‘Let Public See Both CM And PM Houses’: Saurabh Bharadwaj Speaking to the media, Bharadwaj said that the BJP which sent videos and photos of the new CM’s residence on a daily basis is now “running away". “A three-layer barricading has been put up. They have also put up water cannons and deployed Additional DCP here. This has been turned into a border so that the media can’t go in. Show us where the swimming pool and bar are," he said. “BJP says that the CM’s residence was built for Rs 33 Crores. It is also being said that PM house is being built for Rs 2700 Crores. We will see both the CM residence and the PM house. Let the public see both," the Minister added. BJP Reiterates Its ‘Sheesh Mahal’ Charge The Delhi BJP shared a video of the CM residence and questioned where the money for the luxurious renovation came from. The party claimed that there is a “mini-bar" inside the building, a charge that the AAP has strongly rejected. top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all क्या आपने अरविंद केजरीवाल जी के भ्रष्टाचार का शीशमहल देखा है?अगर नहीं देखा है तो आइये आज आपको दिखाते है शीशमहल के अंदर के दुर्लभ दृश्य 👇😳 🚨और कुछ सवाल भी हैं केजरीवाल जी से : झूठ और झांसा देकर सत्ता हासिल करने वाले केजरीवाल ने राजनीति में आने पर कहा था कि बंगला नहीं… pic.twitter.com/q0FXXwyvvf — BJP Delhi (@BJP4Delhi) January 8, 2025 Delhi will go to Assembly polls on February 5 and the counting of votes will be done on February 8. tags : aap BJP delhi elections Delhi polls Location : New Delhi, India First Published: January 08, 2025, 12:02 IST News elections AAP, Delhi Police Clash Over Denied Entry To CM's House Amid 'Sheesh Mahal' Row Read More

title: News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election | Know All About Methodology Behind Mega Survey
summary: The News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election survey interviewed 4,573 respondents across 29 states and Union Territories of India.
full_content: News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election | Know All About Methodology Behind Mega Survey Curated By : News Desk News18.com Last Updated: January 08, 2025, 12:00 IST The News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election survey interviewed 4,573 respondents across 29 states and Union Territories of India. reset Follow us on Google News The data for the survey was collected between December 23 and December 31, 2024. (News18) Is India ready for simultaneous polls? According to News18’s mega survey on One Nation, One Election, the proposal enjoys strong overall support across states, with 80.1 per cent backing the idea nationally. The One Nation, One Election Bills were introduced in the Lok Sabha on December 17 last year and on Wednesday, the first meeting of the Joint Parliamentary Committee (JPC) on simultaneous polls was held. The JPC is mandated to review the Constitution (One Hundred and Twenty-Ninth Amendment) Bill, 2024, and the Union Territories Laws (Amendment) Bill, 2024, which aim to align elections at the national and state levels. It is headed by BJP MP and a former minister of state for law, PP Chaudhary, who called the meeting. related stories METHODOLOGY & SAMPLE SIZE The News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election survey interviewed 4,573 respondents across 29 states and Union Territories of India. The data was collected between December 23 and December 31, 2024. Majority of those interviewed were Hindus — 86.5 per cent — followed by Muslims. Since the fieldwork was mainly restricted to cities and towns, the sample was largely urban at 66.1 per cent, barring the Northeast where a larger rural sample was surveyed. Among the respondents, while males constituted 73.7 per cent, females were at 26.3 per cent. The Northeast, however, had a more sizeable female sample. Most of the respondents fell in the 26-55 years age bracket, comprising 81.7 per cent of the respondents. top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all The sample was also relatively affluent, with nearly two-thirds identified as businessman/trader, landowner (farmer), white collar worker and housewife. The respondents were educated, with more than two-thirds — 68.9 per cent — indicating they had college or higher education. The One Nation, One Election proposal aims to synchronise elections for the Lok Sabha and state assemblies, reducing the frequency of polls and cutting down on expenses. While its supporters argue that the move will minimise disruptions caused by frequent election cycles, the Opposition has flagged logistical challenges and the potential concentration of power. tags : BJP congress JPC News18 Pulse ONOP One Nation-One Election Simultaneous polls Location : New Delhi, India First Published: January 08, 2025, 12:00 IST News elections News18 Pulse: One Nation, One Election | Know All About Methodology Behind Mega Survey Read More

title: Will Raj Thackeray Join Mahayuti Ahead Of Civic Polls? His Meeting With Mumbai BJP Chief Sparks Buzz
summary: Mumbai civic polls: Thackeray has blamed Maharashtra Deputy Chief Minister Eknath Shinde for not being able to join the grand alliance ahead of the recent assembly elections
full_content: Will Raj Thackeray Join Mahayuti Ahead Of Civic Polls? His Meeting With Mumbai BJP Chief Sparks Buzz Curated By : Poulami Kundu News18.com Last Updated: January 08, 2025, 12:22 IST Mumbai civic polls: Thackeray has blamed Maharashtra Deputy Chief Minister Eknath Shinde for not being able to join the grand alliance ahead of the recent assembly elections reset Follow us on Google News Maharashtra Navnirman Sena chief Raj Thackeray with BJP Mumbai chief Ashish Shelar. (Photo: News18) BMC Polls: Maharashtra Navnirman Sena (MNS) chief Raj Thackeray met with BJP Mumbai chief Ashish Shelar late Tuesday, creating a buzz about him joining Mahayuti ahead of the upcoming civic body polls. According to sources, Raj Thackeray did hint at joining the ruling Mahayuti alliance. related stories ‘Eknath Shinde Did Not Want Me In Mahayuti’ Thackeray has blamed Maharashtra Deputy Chief Minister Eknath Shinde for not being able to join the grand alliance ahead of the recent assembly elections, according to a Hindustan Times report. In a meeting he convened to discuss the party’s strategy for the upcoming civic elections, which might take place this year, Thackeray informed his party members that while the BJP was open to an alliance, the then CM Eknath Shinde was not. As a result, MNS could not join the Mahayuti alliance. BJP Eyeing 40 Seats In BMC Polls Meanwhile, Union minister and local MP Piyush Goyal on Saturday said the BJP-led Mahayuti alliance will win 40 seats from north Mumbai in the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) elections. Civic elections are due in the country’s financial capital for more than two years. It is expected that the polls will be held in the next few months, but no announcement has been made yet. The BJP leader, MP from Mumbai North, held a meeting with municipal commissioner Bhushan Gagrani and senior officials of various government departments and bodies including MHADA, Slum Rehabilitation Authority, MMRDA, sports officials, district administration, and police. Projects worth more than Rs 60,000 crore were discussed, Goyal told reporters. This was the third such meeting held by Goyal in five months. Work on projects like the Coastal Road, Lokhandwala DP Road, Malad Development Project, development of playgrounds, construction of cultural centers, parking arrangements in Borivali (East), measures to improve healthcare services, studies and plans regarding the Buddha statue at Sanjay Gandhi National Park, widening and rehabilitation of Poisar River and several other issues were discussed in detail. Efforts were on to get all requisite permissions and start the construction of the Versova to Bhayander stretch of the Coastal Road in the next 45 days, the Union minister said. “There were positive discussions with officials on how issues like healthcare, education, infrastructure, pollution and basic facilities in north Mumbai will be resolved….the Mahayuti alliance will win 40 seats in north Mumbai in the coming elections," he said. top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all The BMC has 236 wards. Goyal also said efforts are being made to enhance the inadequate infrastructure and human resources at the BMC-run Bhagwati, Shatabdi, and Savitribai hospitals. Bhagwati Hospital will begin serving patients by May. Each hospital will provide services to patients through the Ayushman Scheme, he said. title: Difficult To Define 'Freebie', High Time 'Accepted & Legal' Answers Found: CEC Kumar
summary: It is very difficult to define what a "freebie" is and the Election Commission's "hands are tied" on the issue as it is subjudice, CEC Rajiv Kumar said on Tuesday.
full_content: Difficult To Define 'Freebie', High Time 'Accepted & Legal' Answers Found: CEC Kumar Agency: PTI Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 20:02 IST It is very difficult to define what a "freebie" is and the Election Commission's "hands are tied" on the issue as it is subjudice, CEC Rajiv Kumar said on Tuesday. reset Follow us on Google News Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar (Image: ANI) It is very difficult to define what a "freebie" is and the Election Commission’s "hands are tied" on the issue as it is subjudice, CEC Rajiv Kumar said on Tuesday. He also said it was "high time" that "accepted and legal answers" were found. related stories Chief Election Commissioner (CEC) Kumar was addressing a press conference to announce the schedule for the assembly polls in Delhi. Asked about political parties announcing freebies during election campaigns, he said the matter was subjudice and referred to a court judgment that had held freebies were not "disallowed". "What is freebie for me may be an entitlement for someone else… It is very difficult to define what a freebie is," Kumar said. "Our proforma is on our website, this is high time it is accepted and legal answers are found but our hands are tied at the moment because the matter is subjudice," he added. Kumar further said that while such announcements were made, people should also be aware of the state’s fiscal health. "It is necessary to see what is the fiscal health of a state… What is the debt-to-GDP ratio? How much will you borrow on that promise? How much is the financial cost of this promise?" he said. "…We cannot mortgage the future of future generations, this is a very very serious issue," he added. The Election Commission has proposed to amend the Model Code of Conduct to add a proforma to Part VIII (Guidelines on Election Manifesto) of the poll code. It will require political parties to inform voters about the financial feasibility of the promises made in their manifestos and also if they are sustainable within the financial space of the state or the Union government. top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all The proposed proforma seeks details of revenue generation ways (through additional tax, if any), rationalising expenditure (cutting some schemes, if so required), impact on committed liabilities and/or raising of further debt and its impact on Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act (FRBM) limits. The model code is a document that guides the poll panel in ensuring a level playing field for all political parties and candidates during elections. (This story has not been edited by News18 staff and is published from a syndicated news agency feed - PTI ) Location : New Delhi, India First Published: January 07, 2025, 20:02 IST News elections Difficult To Define 'Freebie', High Time 'Accepted & Legal' Answers Found: CEC Kumar Read More

title: Delhi Polls: AIMIM Fields Shafa Ur Rehman Khan From Okhla
summary: The ruling AAP has again fielded its MLA Amanatullah Khan from the constituency, while the BJP and Congress are yet to announce their candidates.
full_content: Delhi Polls: AIMIM Fields Shafa Ur Rehman Khan From Okhla Agency: PTI Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 20:00 IST The ruling AAP has again fielded its MLA Amanatullah Khan from the constituency, while the BJP and Congress are yet to announce their candidates. reset Follow us on Google News AIMIM leader Asaduddin Owaisi (PTI) The Asaduddin Owaisi-led All India Majlis-e-Ittehad-ul-Muslimeen (AIMIM) on Tuesday announced Shafa ur Rehman Khan as its candidate for the Okhla constituency in the upcoming Delhi Assembly elections. The ruling AAP has again fielded its MLA Amanatullah Khan from the constituency, while the BJP and Congress are yet to announce their candidates. top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all related stories Shafa ur Rehman Khan, the President of the Jamia Alumni Association (AAJMI), will represent the party in the crucial election, the party’s Delhi president Shoaib Jamai said on Tuesday. Posting on X, the party said, "An appeal is made to all the voters of the Okhla Assembly constituency to make Shafa ur Rehman Khan victorious with the largest number of votes by pressing the button on the kite symbol on February 5." The Delhi Assembly polls will be held on February 5. The last date to file nominations is January 17, and the scrutiny of nominations will be completed by January 18. (This story has not been edited by News18 staff and is published from a syndicated news agency feed - PTI ) tags : aap AIMIM delhi election delhi elections Location : New Delhi, India First Published: January 07, 2025, 20:00 IST News elections Delhi Polls: AIMIM Fields Shafa Ur Rehman Khan From Okhla Read More

title: 'Voting Wednesday': Mid-Week Polling In Delhi To Deter Voters From Taking Off On Long Weekend
summary: All 13,033 polling stations in Delhi are urban, and it has been a massive challenge for the Election Commission to get urban voters to booths despite all its efforts in other cities
full_content: 'Voting Wednesday': Mid-Week Polling In Delhi To Deter Voters From Taking Off On Long Weekend Reported By : Nivedita Singh News18.com Edited By: Oindrila Mukherjee Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 18:15 IST All 13,033 polling stations in Delhi are urban, and it has been a massive challenge for the Election Commission to get urban voters to booths despite all its efforts in other cities reset Follow us on Google News The voter turnout in Delhi in the 2020 assembly polls was almost 63%, and polling took place on a Saturday. (Image: PTI/File) Karnataka in 2023 and Maharashtra in 2024 – for both elections, polling took place in the middle of the week. And now it is Delhi’s turn on February 5, which is a Wednesday, as the Election Commission once again uses mid-week voting to combat urban apathy . All 13,033 polling stations in Delhi are urban, and it has been a massive challenge for the Election Commission of India (ECI) to get urban voters to booths despite all its efforts in other cities. It also happens to be a single-phase election as all 70 assembly constituencies in Delhi go to polls on the same day. related stories The EC started using mid-week polling as a means to discourage voters from planning mini-breaks and weekend getaways, so as to fight urban apathy towards voting. This was first attempted in March 2023 when the dates for the Karnataka polls were announced. Although there was not much improvement in the urban voter turnout, there was still a slight increase at 55 per cent from 54.6 per cent in 2018. ALSO READ | Numberspeak: UP’s Ghaziabad, Gautam Buddha Nagar Saw Lowest Voter Turnout Since 2014; Here’s What Caused It When it first announced the Haryana polls, it was decided that voting would be conducted on October 1, 2024 (Tuesday), but later the dates were changed to October 5 (Saturday). The consequences were that parts of Gurugram and Faridabad witnessed poor voter turnout, with some booths registering only 20 per cent. This means for every 100 voters, only 20 came out to vote. But, when Maharashtra went to polls in November 2024, voting took place on November 20, again a Wednesday. It worked well and the voter turnout improved by close to six percentage points from 2019 to 56 per cent in Mumbai, despite the city reporting the lowest participation in the state. In Lok Sabha, this could not be practiced and the impact was seen across cities. The first two phases were conducted on a Friday and, both times, the voter turnout was lower than in 2019, except for some constituencies. The fourth and fifth phases were conducted on a Monday while the final two phases were held on a Saturday. ALSO READ | Lok Sabha Elections 2024: Baramulla Surpasses Voter Turnout in Mumbai, Thane, Amethi, Lucknow in Fifth Phase top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all The voter turnout in Delhi was below 60 per cent during the Lok Sabha polls when voting took place on May 25 (a Saturday). In the 2020 assembly polls, it was almost 63 per cent and the voting took place on a Saturday. An EC official told News18 that while this may not be a 100 percent solution, it is the minimum they can do. “There are a lot of efforts from the commission to increase voter turnout. From running awareness drives to various competitions, we try to reach each and every voter. Mid-week polling is also an attempt from our side," the official said. tags : delhi election Election Commission of India Location : New Delhi, India First Published: January 07, 2025, 18:15 IST News elections 'Voting Wednesday': Mid-Week Polling In Delhi To Deter Voters From Taking Off On Long Weekend Read More

title: Milkipur Bypoll On February 5: Ayodhya Seat To See Fierce Adityanath Vs Akhilesh Battle
summary: UP bypoll on February 5: The SP has announced Awadhesh Prasad’s son Ajit as its candidate for Milkipur. The BJP hasn't announced a candidate yet
full_content: Milkipur Bypoll On February 5: Ayodhya Seat To See Fierce Adityanath Vs Akhilesh Battle Reported By : Oliver Fredrick News18.com Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 17:46 IST UP bypoll on February 5: The SP has announced Awadhesh Prasad’s son Ajit as its candidate for Milkipur. The BJP hasn't announced a candidate yet reset Follow us on Google News Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath and Samajwadi Party (SP) chief Akhilesh Yadav (right). (File images) Even before the Election Commission (EC) on Tuesday announced February 5 as the date for bypoll in Ayodhya’s Milkipur, political parties began pulling out all stops to sway the electorate. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has set its sights on ‘Mission Milkipur’ in Uttar Pradesh. Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath recently said: “If Kundarki could be won, then why not Milkipur?" The statement caused a stir in UP’s political circles, significantly raising the stakes for the upcoming bypoll. related stories The BJP has deployed six ministers to keep a vigilant eye on Milkipur, with CM Adityanath overseeing electoral preparations. On the other hand, the Samajwadi Party (SP) is banking on its trusted Picchda Dalit Alpsankhyak (PDA) formula to consolidate its vote base, setting the stage for an intense political battle. The bypoll is necessitated as Awadhesh Prasad, the MLA of Milkipur, which falls in Ayodhya on the border of Amethi and Sultanpur, got elected as an MP from Faizabad (Ayodhya). Schedule !!General Election to Legislative Assembly of NCT of Delhi, 2025 & Bye-Elections to two ACs namely 273-Milkipur in UP & 98-Erode (East) in TN #DelhiElections2025 #DelhiDecides pic.twitter.com/k0ijQHTgPR — Election Commission of India (@ECISVEEP) January 7, 2025 UP CM’S STATEMENT “The BJP won Kundarki in Moradabad last year with record votes, despite 65% Muslim population in the constituency. It got votes in the name of development. It was due to party workers that we succeeded in winning seven of the nine seats in the UP bypolls," said Adityanath. The UP CM was addressing party workers at Acharya Narendra Dev Agricultural University in Ayodhya. He also told workers to get maximum votes at their respective booths. “Contact and communication is the best way to win. Party workers should compete among themselves to win their booth, gram sabha and mandal with maximum votes," the CM said. WHY KUNDARKI IS A BENCHMARK The UP CM’s statement created a flutter in political circles. “The Milkipur bypoll is no less than a battle of prestige for the BJP, especially after it lost the Ayodhya Lok Sabha seat to the SP in the April-June general elections in 2024. Of the other 9 seats for which bypolls were held, the Kundarki seat was critical, especially due to its complex caste equations. However, the BJP managed a decisive victory in the Muslim-dominated Kundarki seat in Moradabad, traditionally an SP stronghold. This also sets the benchmark and hence the party is in plans to apply the same strategy in Milkipur," said Shashikant Pandey, head department of political science Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University, Lucknow. SPLIT IN MUSLIM VOTES A KEY FACTOR IN KUNDARKI SUCCESS BJP’s Ramveer Thakur won Kundarki after a long wait of 31 years, with a margin of over 1.4 lakh. His closest rival and three-time MLA, SP’s Haji Rizwan, lost his bail amount, securing a mere 25,580 votes. Thakur created history by being the only Hindu candidate from the Muslim-dominated seat. “A split in Muslim votes was the main reason behind the BJP’s win. Barring the BJP, all parties, including the SP, fielded Muslim candidates," said Pandey. Adityanath also urged six ministers and party functionaries to intensify poll preparations and electorate mobilisation in Ayodhya’s Milkipur. While the BJP plans to push for Hindu unity with slogans such as ‘Batenge toh katenge’ (If we are divided, we’ll be slaughtered), the SP aims to retain its stronghold with its PDA strategy. MILKIPUR LIKELY TO SEE ‘PASI VS PASI’ There are rumours that the BJP may field former Milkipur MLA Baba Gorakhnath, a Pasi, who narrowly lost to SP’s Awadhesh Prasad in 2022 by 13,000 votes. Notably, in 2017, Gorakhnath, then 32, defeated the 72-year-old Prasad by more than 26,000 votes, a victory that coincided with the BJP’s landslide win in Uttar Pradesh and Adityanath’s rise to the chief minister’s office. The SP, too, is gearing up for the poll battle and is set to bank on its trusted PDA formula. The SP has fielded Awadhesh Prasad’s son, Ajit, a Pasi, turning the contest into a ‘Pasi vs Pasi’ battle in Milkipur, which has a significant Dalit and OBC population. MILKIPUR BYPOLL ON FEBRUARY 5 While announcing last month’s bypolls for 10 vacant assembly seats of UP, the Election Commission of India (ECI) had skipped Milkipur following a writ petition filed by BJP candidate Baba Gorakhnath, who contested the 2022 assembly elections from the seat. top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all Gorakhnath had challenged the victory...

title: Akhilesh Extends Support To AAP Ahead Of Delhi Assembly Polls, BSP To Go Solo
summary: Samajwadi Party to extend support to Aam Aadmi Party in the upcoming Delhi Assembly polls. While BSP has decided to go solo.
full_content: Akhilesh Extends Support To AAP Ahead Of Delhi Assembly Polls, BSP To Go Solo Curated By : Mahima Joshi News18.com Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 16:54 IST Samajwadi Party to extend support to Aam Aadmi Party in the upcoming Delhi Assembly polls. While BSP has decided to go solo. reset Follow us on Google News Samajwadi Party chief Ahilesh Yadav, AAP convenor Arvind Kejriwal and Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) chief Mayawati. (Image: PTI) Soon after the Election Commission announced the dates for the Delhi Assembly election, Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav extended his support to the Aam Aadmi Party for the upcoming polls in the national capital, scheduled to take place on February 5. Following Akhilesh’s announcement, AAP convener and former Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal thanked Akhilesh thanked him and wrote, “Thank you very much Akhilesh ji. You always support and stand with us. I and the people of Delhi are grateful for this." related stories Notably, this is not the first time that Akhilesh Yadav has extended support to AAP. Last month, Akhilesh Yadav joined Arvind Kejriwal at AAP’s ‘Mahila Adalat’ campaign in Delhi and said that AAP should again get a chance to serve people in Delhi. BSP To Go Solo In Delhi Polls Meanwhile, Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) chief Mayawati said that her party will go solo in the upcoming polls in the national capital. 1. दिल्ली विधानसभा का आमचुनाव आगामी 5 फरवरी 2025 को एक चरण में होगा। चुनाव आयोग द्वारा इस बारे में की गयी घोषणा का स्वागत। बीएसपी यह चुनाव अपनी पूरी तैयारी व दमदारी के साथ अकेले अपने बलबूते पर लड़ रही है। उम्मीद है कि पार्टी इस चुनाव में ज़रूर बेहतर प्रदर्शन करेगी।— Mayawati (@Mayawati) January 7, 2025 Notably, the BSP contested all the 70 seats in Delhi in the 2020 Assembly election but failed to win any. However, the party secured a vote share of 0.71 per cent. The party contested all 70 seats in the capital in 2015, 2013 and 2008 as well. Delhi Polls To Take Pace On February 5 The elections to the 70-member Delhi Assembly are set to take place on February 5 and the votes for the same will be counted on February 8. The national capital will witness a triangular contest between the AAP, BJP and Congress. The Arvind Kejriwal-led party swept the 2015 and 2020 elections with 67 and 62 top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all seats, respectively. On the other hand, the BJP was reduced to just single digits in the last two elections. Meanwhile, the Congress party, which once ruled Delhi for 15 years, will now be contesting the polls alone after having stitched an alliance with the AAP for the 2024 Lok Sabha polls. tags : aap Akhilesh Yadav Bahujan samaj party delhi elections samajwadi party Location : New Delhi, India First Published: January 07, 2025, 16:28 IST News elections Akhilesh Extends Support To AAP Ahead Of Delhi Assembly Polls, BSP To Go Solo Read More

title: Delhiites, You Can Now Vote From Home. What Is The Process And Who Can Apply?
summary: Delhi Elections 2025: To make the process inclusive and accessible, the ECI extended its ‘vote-from-home’ facility to Persons with Disabilities (PwD) and senior citizens aged 85 and above.
full_content: Delhiites, You Can Now Vote From Home. What Is The Process And Who Can Apply? Curated By : Mallika Soni News18.com Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 15:18 IST Delhi Elections 2025: To make the process inclusive and accessible, the ECI extended its ‘vote-from-home’ facility to Persons with Disabilities (PwD) and senior citizens aged 85 and above. reset Follow us on Google News Delhi Elections 2025: Delhi Assembly election will be held in a single phase on February 5. Votes will be counted on February 8. The Election Commission of India (ECI) said that the Delhi Assembly election will be held in a single phase on February 5. Votes will be counted on February 8 in the election which will determine the fate of the Aam Aadmi Party-government, led by Arvind Kejriwal, in the national capital. As per the latest figures by the Election Commission, Delhi’s voter base has grown significantly in the past two months as in October 2024, the total number of voters stood at 1,53,57,529 which rose to 1,55,24,858 new electorates in December 2024. related stories Read more: ‘We Follow Narratives That Suit Us’: In Rajiv Kumar’s EVM Defence, A Mention Of Two Elon Musk Posts To make the process inclusive and accessible, the ECI extended its ‘vote-from-home’ facility to Persons with Disabilities (PwD) and senior citizens aged 85 and above. Who is eligible to vote from home in Delhi? top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all The home voting facility can be used by senior citizens and PwD candidates. The benchmark disability should be not less than 40% of the specified disability as certified by the concerned certifying authority. Those who opt for voting from home are not eligible to vote directly at the polling station on polling day. Home voting was extended for eligible voters in the entire country during the Lok Sabha elections 2024. At the time, Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar said, “Generally the tendency has been that the senior citizens want to participate in the process and walk to the booth. But this time, we have given them options to vote in their homes." tags : delhi assembly election delhi election delhi election date Location : Delhi, India First Published: January 07, 2025, 15:18 IST News india Delhiites, You Can Now Vote From Home. What Is The Process And Who Can Apply? Read More

title: EC Poll Bugle In Delhi Triggers Poster War Between AAP, BJP
summary: The BJP Delhi unit has released a poster featuring PM Modi, promising a "double engine government" in Delhi on February 8, the vote-counting day.
full_content: EC Poll Bugle In Delhi Triggers Poster War Between AAP, BJP Curated By : Vani Mehrotra News18.com Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 16:15 IST The BJP Delhi unit has released a poster featuring PM Modi, promising a "double engine government" in Delhi on February 8, the vote-counting day. reset Follow us on Google News Delhi BJP releases poster (L)/Arvind Kejriwal (R) (Photos: @BJP4Delhi/PTI) Minutes after Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar announced the date for the assembly elections in Delhi, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP)’s Delhi unit on Tuesday released a poster, mentioning that the saffron party is coming to Delhi on February 8 – the day the votes will be counted. In a social media post, the BJP wrote, “On February 8, Delhi will get a double engine government, the development of the capital will gain speed and Delhiites will get the gift of public welfare schemes of the Center." related stories The party’s newly-released poster featured Prime Minister Narendra Modi. 08 फरवरी को दिल्ली को मिलेगी डबल इंजन सरकार, राजधानी के विकास को मिलेगी रफ्तार और दिल्लीवासियों को मिलेगा केंद्र की जनहित योजनाओं का उपहार #आ_रही_है_भाजपा pic.twitter.com/oj6RZDHbnZ — BJP Delhi (@BJP4Delhi) January 7, 2025 Defence minister Rajnath Singh also expressed confidence that the BJP will emerge victorious in the Delhi polls. Meanwhile, in an X post, former Chief Minister and Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) convenor Arvind Kejriwal wrote, “The date of the election has been announced. All the workers should be ready to enter the fray with full strength and enthusiasm. Their big systems fail in front of your passion. You are our biggest strength." “This election will be between the politics of work and the politics of abuse. The people of Delhi will have faith in our politics of work. We will definitely win," a rough translation of his post in Hindi suggested. चुनाव की तारीख़ का एलान हो चुका है। सभी कार्यकर्ता पूरी ताक़त और जोश के साथ मैदान में उतरने के लिए तैयार हो जाएं। आपके जुनून के आगे इनके बड़े-बड़े तंत्र फ़ेल हो जाते हैं। आप ही हमारी सबसे बड़ी ताक़त हैं।ये चुनाव काम की राजनीति और गाली-गलौज की राजनीति के बीच होगा। दिल्ली की… — Arvind Kejriwal (@ArvindKejriwal) January 7, 2025 Reposting Kejriwal’s post, the BJP’s IT cell chief Amit Malviya wrote, “Congress candidate from New Delhi Sandeep Dixit is saying that AAP does not have workers but daily wage labourers. Will you not answer them? However, this time the people of Delhi themselves have entered the electoral fray with full force. Now they will not tolerate injustice any more. There will be a change, AAP-D will go and BJP will come." नई दिल्ली से कांग्रेस के प्रत्याशी संदीप दीक्षित कह रहे हैं कि आप-दा के पास कार्यकर्ता नहीं, बल्कि दिहाड़ी के मजदूर हैं। उन्हें जवाब नहीं देंगे?वैसे दिल्ली के लोग इस बार खुद चुनावी मैदान में पूरी ताकत के साथ उतर चुके हैं। अब और अन्याय बर्दाश्त नहीं करेंगे। बदलाव होगा, आप-दा… https://t.co/rRtnB4BXad — Amit Malviya (@amitmalviya) January 7, 2025 Echoing Malviya, the BJP’s chief JP Nadda wrote, “ I welcome the Election Commission of India’s announcement of the Delhi Assembly Elections." “PM Narendra Modi ji, the BJP government has been continuously working towards the comprehensive development of Delhi and will further our efforts to turn the dream of a ‘Viksit Delhi’ into a reality," he added. I welcome the Election Commission of India’s announcement of the Delhi Assembly Elections.Elections are the biggest festival of democracy. They are a medium to keep the country and the state advancing on the path of development and good governance. I urge the people of Delhi… — Jagat Prakash Nadda (@JPNadda) January 7, 2025 Addressing a press conference, BJP Delhi president Virendra Sachdeva said, “ We welcome the schedule that has been announced. February 5 is a date of change. ‘ Aapda ‘ government will go and the BJP government will come to power on February 8." Also speaking to reporters, AAP leader Manish Sisodia said, “ I want to congratulate and wish the people of Delhi as elections will be held on February 5, and people of Delhi will once again elect Arvind Kejriwal, they will once again vote for the party that provides free education to their children, they will once again choose a Chief Minister who ensure good healthcare to their families." “Fake names of applicants are being used to remove the names of voters on a large scale. Is the Election Commission taking action against them? What action has been taken against those who were found distributing Rs 1100?" Sisodia asked. During a press conference held later in the day following the release of the election schedule, AAP’s Saurabh Bharadwaj told reporters that the BJP prefers attacking leaders instead of finding ways to improve the lives of the people of Delhi. Snatched Official Residence Delhi CM Atishi said as soon as the poll dates were announced she received “a notice from the BJP government" asking her to vacate her official residence. “Today the elections were announced in Delhi. On the eve of the ann...

title: 'Hum Ho Na Ho...': CEC Rajiv Kumar's 'Shayaris' Go Viral Amid Delhi Election Dates Announcement | Video
summary: Delhi Elections 2025: What makes Chief Election Commissioner (CEC) Rajiv Kumar's media interaction different is his style of addressing using 'shayari' or Urdu poetry.
full_content: 'Hum Ho Na Ho...': CEC Rajiv Kumar's 'Shayaris' Go Viral Amid Delhi Election Dates Announcement | Video Curated By : News Desk News18.com Edited By: Sumedha Kirti Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 16:22 IST Delhi Elections 2025: What makes Chief Election Commissioner (CEC) Rajiv Kumar's media interaction different is his style of addressing using 'shayari' or Urdu poetry. reset Follow us on Google News Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar (Image: ANI) Before every elections, the Election Commission of India holds a press conference to inform the dates for voting and counting of votes. This is the process that all election commissioners follow, irrespective of annoucement for state or general elections. However, what makes Chief Election Commissioner (CEC) Rajiv Kumar’s media interaction different is his style of addressing using ‘shayari’ or Urdu poetry. The announcement for 2025 Delhi election dates was no different. While responding to those questioning EVMs and the electoral process, Kumar on Tuesday said: “ Sab sawaal ki ehmiyat rakhte hain, jawab toh banta hai. Aadatan qalam-band jawab dete rahe, aaj roobaru bhi banta hai. Kya pata kal ho na ho, aaj jawab toh banta hai. " related stories This loosely translates to: All questions are important. Hence, we must answer them. We usually have a habit of replying in writing but we must respond face-to-face today. We never know if tomorrow comes or not, hence replying to questions today is important. The second ‘shayari’ came while Kumar was talking about political leaders who come out with allegations of ballot rigging after election results. “ Kar na sakein ikraar toh koi baat nahi, meri wafa ka unko aitbaar toh hai. Shikayat bhale hi unki majboori ho, magar sunna, sehna, suljhana humari aadat toh hai ." This poetry loosely translates to: It’s alright even if they don’t agree. They still have faith in my loyalty. May be complaining is a compulsion for them. But it’s our habit to listen, bear and sort things out. Reciting his third ‘shayari’ on those doubting the work of Election Commission, Rajiv Kumar said, “ Aaropon aur ilzamaat ka daur chale, koi gila nahi. Jhooth ke gubbaron ko bulandi mile, koi shikwa nahi. Har parinaam mein pramaand dete hain par woh bina saboot shakk ki nayi duniya raunak karte hain. Aur shakk ka ilaaj toh haqeem luqman ke paas bhi nahi ." The above poetry loosely translates to: I have no complaints in this era of blame game and allegations, neither will I object to balloons of lies flying high. We keep giving proof on every result day but they keep lighting a new world of doubts without any evidence. And there’s no cure for doubts — neither a wise man can help nor a physician. All the concerns raised by Congress party have been answered by CEC Rajiv Kumar through his shayaris. 3 shayari for all the questions and accountability done…! pic.twitter.com/hpevSWb3w7 — Venisha G Kiba (@KibaVenisha) January 7, 2025 The poetries of CEC Rajiv often go viral. Earlier, his impromptu poetry during the Lok Sabha Election 2024 schedule announcement was widely circulated on social media. "EVM shayari" by the Chief Election Commissioner to those who do EVM propaganda every time 😂 pic.twitter.com/QvVTn33ixc — Keh Ke Peheno (@coolfunnytshirt) March 16, 2024 “ Jhooth ke bazaar mei raunak toh bohot hai, goya bul bule jaisi hi turant hi phat jati hai, pakad bhi loge toh kya hasil hoga sivaye dokhe ke . (In the market of lies, there is much splendor, as if it were a bubble that bursts immediately, and if you try to catch it, what will you gain except deceit.)" top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all Similarly, during the announcement of voting dates for Jammu and Kashmir (a state that has seen unrest on multiple occasions in the past), Kumar had recited: “ Lambi kataaron mein hai badalte surat-e-haal ki kahani, roshan umeedein karengi goya apne taqdeeron ki bayani. Jumooriyat ke jashn mein aapki shirqat, duniya dekhegi naapaak iradon ke shiqast ki kahani ." His poetry translates to: The story of the changing circumstances is in long lines. The bright hopes will narrate its tale. With your participation in the celebration of democracy, the world will see the story of defeat of evil intentions. tags : delhi elections New Delhi Rajiv Kumar Location : New Delhi, India First Published: January 07, 2025, 15:05 IST News india 'Hum Ho Na Ho...': CEC Rajiv Kumar's 'Shayaris' Go Viral Amid Delhi Election Dates Announcement | Video Read More

title: How Prashant Kishor, Disruptor In Bihar Triangle, Is Redrawing Electoral Battle Lines
summary: By tying his personal actions to the larger narrative of political accountability, Kishor is trying to position himself as a champion of transparency and justice, appealing to voters who are wary of the old political guard
full_content: How Prashant Kishor, Disruptor In Bihar Triangle, Is Redrawing Electoral Battle Lines Written By : Madhuparna Das News18.com Edited By: Apoorva Misra Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 14:49 IST By tying his personal actions to the larger narrative of political accountability, Kishor is trying to position himself as a champion of transparency and justice, appealing to voters who are wary of the old political guard reset Follow us on Google News Prashant Kishor’s political-electoral strategy seems to be a calculated mix of grassroots mobilisation, some direct actions along with an emotional appeal, and having a high-pitched sub-regionalism. (PTI) In the complex, caste-driven political landscape of Bihar, chief minister Nitish Kumar and RJD leader Lalu Prasad Yadav now seem to be maneuvering to maintain their political relevance. Amidst this, Prashant Kishor, with his Jan Suraaj Party, emerges as the potential political disruptor—not by securing seats or forming alliances, but by siphoning votes that could alter electoral outcomes. Kishor’s current approach to the BPSC (Bihar Public Service Commission) scam has revealed a deeper, wisely calculated political strategy which goes beyond just reacting to the issue at hand. His decision to start a hunger strike until the demand for re-examination is met, and his willingness to court arrest — including his refusal to sign a bail bond to remain in jail — speaks volumes about his political acumen and his intent. related stories The BPSC protest move is not merely about protesting against the scam. Instead, it is more about positioning himself as the voice of the people, especially Bihar’s youth, and also against an alleged corrupt system in the state as it is to go to polls in the next nine to 10 months. In the caste-based fractured society in the state, Kishor’s decision to take such a bold stance comes at a time when Bihar’s political landscape is readying for a major shift that may be seen in the next assembly polls. This clearly indicates how Kishor is capitalising on the growing and pent-up discontent surrounding issues like corruption, governance, and mismanagement in Bihar, all of which may sway public opinion in the lead-up to the state elections. By tying his personal actions to the larger narrative of political accountability, Kishor is now trying to position himself as a champion of transparency and justice, appealing to voters who are wary of the old political guard. Jan Suraaj and its sunlight moment Kishor’s Jan Suraaj Party, which that was floated with much pomp and show on Mahatma Gandhi’s birthday on October 2, 2024, fought its first-ever election next month as the state saw bypolls in four assembly constituencies. The party, which was still at a nascent stage, fought on all four seats that went to bypolls. It had a strong showing in the bypolls, where it secured over 23 per cent votes on Imamganj seat and more than 11 per cent in Belganj, further solidifying Kishor’s political standing. For a first-time electoral outing, these results are quite impressive, signaling that Kishor’s message somewhat resonates with a significant portion of the electorate, despite the limited time and resources available to his party. This electoral success, combined with his latest protest actions, reflect that Kishor is not just looking to be a fleeting political figure, but is also preparing to be a key player in Bihar’s upcoming elections. His political-electoral strategy seems to be a calculated mix of grassroots mobilisation, some direct actions along with an emotional appeal, and having a high-pitched sub-regionalism or commonly called sub-nationalism through his slogan ‘Jai Bihar’. By taking such a visible stand against the BPSC scam, Kishor is not only addressing an issue that affects the common man and the unemployed but aspirational youth of Bihar, but also positioning himself as someone willing to fight for the people, even if it means taking a few personal risks. It is surely a message that aligns well with the electorate’s growing desire for change and reform in Bihar’s politics, especially as the state gears up for its next round of electoral battles. The sharp edge of the Bihar triangle Political experts feel that if Kishor continues with the momentum he created, he will be able to damage the voter base of both political stalwarts of Bihar — Nitish Kumar and Lalu Yadav. As both these politicians are now part of national alliances — NDA and INDIA bloc respectively — Kishor’s outreach may bring more harm to the RJD than it does to the JDU. top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all “Prashant Kishor has already done the frontal attack on JDU’s governance, exposing its failures in education policy and the BPSC scandal. However, he always attacked RJD more on several occasions. Now, he’s playing a selective game with the BJP, focusing on their vulnerabilities to further his political ambitions. It seems to be a mixture of strategy by targeting Bihar’s...

title: Delhi Dangal Dates Out, A Look At 3 Key Issues That Dominated The Election Narrative
summary: Delhi Elections: The first major electoral battle of 2025 will see a triangular contest among the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP), Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), and Congress
full_content: Delhi Dangal Dates Out, A Look At 3 Key Issues That Dominated The Election Narrative Curated By : News Desk News18.com Edited By: Apoorva Misra Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 14:44 IST Delhi Elections: The first major electoral battle of 2025 will see a triangular contest among the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP), Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), and Congress reset Follow us on Google News The term of the Delhi assembly is due to end on February 23. (AP) The stage is all set for the Delhi Dangal. The Election Commission on Tuesday announced the dates for the high-stakes assembly election to the Capital where voting will take place on February 5 and the results will be announced on February 8. The first major electoral battle of 2025 will see a triangular contest among the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP), Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), and Congress. The term of the Delhi assembly is due to end on February 23. related stories For the AAP, which has battled corruption charges and seen its top brass cool their heels in prison, the elections are a litmus test to prove that the party — which was birthed from an anti-corruption movement — still rules over the hearts of Delhiites. Arvind Kejriwal’s party, which has ruled Delhi with a full majority since 2015, is hoping that its schemes such as free electricity, water, and free bus rides for women, apart from a monthly stipend of Rs 2,100, free healthcare for the elderly, and a waiver of inflated water bills will help it retain power in the Capital. Meanwhile, the BJP, which has been out of power in Delhi for over 26 years, is keen to claw back power from Kejriwal and AAP. In a scathing attack on AAP, Prime Minister Narendra Modi, while kicking off BJP’s poll campaign, equated its rule in Delhi to “AAPda (disaster)". The saffron party has upped the ante against the ruling AAP by targeting Kejriwal’s extravagant expenditure on the CM’s bungalow when he held the top post. For the Congress, the 2025 contest is a do-or-die battle. The Grand Old Party has been unable to open its account in the Capital — which it ruled for 15 years — in the previous two elections. Snubbed by the AAP, with whom it is fighting on the national level as part of the INDIA bloc, the Congress has been trying to revive its fortunes. It has promised Rs 2,500 monthly to women under the ‘Pyaari Didi Yojana’ if voted back to power. As the political temperatures rise, let’s take a look at key issues that have dominated and will continue to drive the Delhi discourse: CORRUPTION In an ironic turn of events, the AAP, which came to power on the anti-corruption plank, was embroiled in a liquor scam, faced cases of money laundering, and even faced barbs over the expensive renovation at the chief minister’s residence. The party’s top brass was forced to spend time in jail, ranging from six months to two years. However, now out on bail, the AAP has hit the electoral track running and accused the BJP of trying to implicate its leaders to intimidate them into jumping ship. The BJP, meanwhile, has accused Kejriwal of being the master puppeteer who knows all about the scams right under his nose. The party, while sharpening its attack on the former CM’s ‘Sheesh Mahal’, accused the AAP convener of diverting people’s money to fund his extravagant project. Home Minister Amit Shah alleged that over Rs 6 crore was spent on designer marbles, Rs 6 crore on motorised curtains, Rs 70 lakh on automatic doors, Rs 50 lakh on carpets and Rs 64 lakh on smart TVs at the chief minister’s residence when Kejriwal occupied it. The voter sentiment on the corruption issue seems divided. While many believe the AAP is a victim of vendetta politics, others feel the party has lost its sheen and joined the bandwagon of tainted outfits. CIVIC ISSUES Mounds of garbage, overflowing drains, water shortage or supply of dirty water and damaged roads have become major issues for voters in the Capital. While the BJP blames AAP for the urban apathy, the latter claims the saffron party has only tried to defame it and stall the work of the MCD. Delhi’s dwindling air quality, which returns to haunt the Capital in winters every year, has also become a bone of contention between the two parties. Unfortunately, the ultimate losers in the tug-of-war are Delhiites who are forced to deal with unaddressed civic issues. top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all ROW OVER VOTER ROLLS The controversy over the alleged manipulation of electoral rolls in the Capital escalated after Delhi Chief Minister Atishi wrote to the Chief Election Commissioner, seeking another round of verification of the voter deletions in the New Delhi assembly constituency. The revised voter list on Monday triggered the AAP, which accused the EC of indulging in “large-scale voter deletion fraud" even as the BJP claimed AAP failed to “register fake voters, especially Rohingya and Bangladeshi individuals" this time. tags : aam aadmi party arvind kejriwal BJP congress delhi elections election commissio...

title: Delhi Election 2025 Date: Voting On February 5, Counting On February 8, ECI Announces Full Schedule
summary: Delhi Assembly Election 2025 Schedule: The AAP had swept the 2020 Delhi elections, winning 62 out of the 70 Assembly seats while the BJP had won the remaining eight.
full_content: Delhi Election 2025 Date: Voting On February 5, Counting On February 8, ECI Announces Full Schedule Curated By : News Desk News18.com Edited By: Pragati Ratti Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 15:23 IST Delhi Assembly Election 2025 Schedule: The AAP had swept the 2020 Delhi elections, winning 62 out of the 70 Assembly seats while the BJP had won the remaining eight. reset Follow us on Google News CEC Rajiv Kumar announces dates for Delhi Assembly Elections 2025. Delhi Assembly Election 2025 Schedule: The Election Commission of India (ECI) on Tuesday announced the full schedule for Delhi Assembly Elections 2025. Voting for the Delhi polls will take place on February 5 in a single phase while the counting of votes will take place on February 8. Ahead of the announcement of poll dates , the Chief Electoral Officer on Monday released the final electoral roll of Delhi, which shows that the national capital has 1,55,24,858 voters. The number increased by 1.09 per cent since the publication of the October 29, 2024, draft of electors. Delhi has 70 constituencies (58 General and 12 SC sets). related stories Poll event Date Notification date 10 January 2025 Last date for filing nomination 17 January 2025 Scrutiny of nomination 18 January 2025 Last date for withdrawal of nomination 20 January 2025 Date of Poll 5 February 2025 Date of counting of Votes 8 February 2025 CEC Addresses Questions On EVMs Speaking on the doubts and questions surrounding the electoral roll, Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar said, “ Electoral rolls are a product of transparency and participation. Political parties are involved at each and every stage of preparation of v oter list. There is full disclosure and an opportunity to object is given. In deletions or additions, due process is followed rigorously." He also dismissed doubts raised by the Congress and other parties on Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) and the election procedure. “There were certain kinds of concerns that were raised (by political parties). It was said that wrongful addition and deletion were made in electoral rolls… It was also said that certain groups are targeted and their names are deleted. Even after giving a reply about EVM – it was said that EVM can be manipulated. However, 15 different parties emerged as the s ingle largest across 30 states/UTs elections since Bihar state elections in 2020, " the CEC said. “There has not even been one difference in 4.5 crore VVPAT slips counted so far in various elections," Kumar added, stressing on the credibility of the Indian election process. Three-Way Battle The national capital is seeing a three-way battle with the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) seeking a third terms while the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and Congress are looking to challenge the Arvind Kejriwal-led party and each other. The AAP had swept the 2020 Delhi elections, winning 62 out of the 70 Assembly seats while the BJP had won the remaining eight. This election, all the three parties in the fray have said they are confident of winning Delhi elections. Congress candidate from New Delhi assembly constituency, Sandeep Dikshit said, “Congress is prepared for the elections. We are putting forth our vision for Delhi before the people. The issues which are there will remain and we will keep questioning the current Delhi government." top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all BJP candidate from Gandhi Nagar Assembly seat Arvinder Singh Lovely said, “After PM Narendra Modi’s address in Rohini, people of Delhi are in full mood to kick out the corrupt and fake AAP… people of Delhi are tired of listening to his accusations for not being able to work…" Delhi minister and AAP leader Gopal Rai said, “Our preparations for the elections have been completed. Our candidates are working on the ground. The people in Delhi are ready to elect a govt that works, they are ready to elect Arvind Kejriwal… BJP has no CM face; they neither have an agenda nor the leaders. They have already conceded defeat." tags : delhi elections Election Commission of India (ECI) Location : New Delhi, India First Published: January 07, 2025, 14:43 IST News elections Delhi Election 2025 Date: Voting On February 5, Counting On February 8, ECI Announces Full Schedule Read More

title: In Rajiv Kumar's EVM Defence, A Mention Of Two Elon Musk Posts: 'We Follow Narratives That Suit Us'
summary: Kumar referred to Elon Musk's comments that EVMs can be hacked, which created a pandemonium in India. Musk later acknowledged India's electoral system where all votes were counted in a single day.
full_content: In Rajiv Kumar's EVM Defence, A Mention Of Two Elon Musk Posts: 'We Follow Narratives That Suit Us' Curated By : Aveek Banerjee News18.com Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 15:45 IST Kumar referred to Elon Musk's comments that EVMs can be hacked, which created a pandemonium in India. Musk later acknowledged India's electoral system where all votes were counted in a single day. reset Follow us on Google News Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar addressing a press conference to announce Delhi poll schedule. (ECI) While announcing the schedule of Delhi Assembly elections, Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar attempted to dispel the notions of Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) being hacked by recalling tech mogul Elon Musk’s remarks last year that added fuel to the fire surrounding the debate on EVM credibility. The poll panel chief started answering the questions raised against alleged electoral roll, EVMs and voter turnout manipulation using his usual style of Shayaris, beginning by saying, “Aaj Jawab Toh Banta Hai." related stories Without mentioning his name, Kumar referred to Elon Musk’s previous remarks calling for EVMS to be “eliminated" as they were at the risk of being hacked by humans or artificial intelligence. Musk had asserted that paper ballots were crucial for honest and fair elections. “It’s a misconceived narrative. A global IT expert said EVMs can be hacked while our elections were going on. They (America) don’t have EVMs, they have electronic voting mechanisms. The remarks created a pandemonium here. The same expert later said that India takes a single day to finish counting while the US takes over a month. We just follow the narratives that are suiting," Kumar said at the presser. The Chief Election Commissioner staunchly defended the voting system and rubbished the opposition’s claims of EVM tampering. After the recently held Maharashtra elections, concerns were raised by opposition parties over the surge in voter turnout post-evening. “EVMs are tamper-proof. They undergo scrutiny at every stage. From commissioning, which takes place around 7-8 days before polling day, to counting, the EVMs are never out of the sight of the candidate and officials even once and at every step, political party agents and candidates are informed," he said, adding that there was no question of hacking or rigging an EVM. What Did Elon Musk Say On EVMs? In June, just after the Lok Sabha elections that saw Prime Minister Narendra Modi returning to a historic third term in India, Elon Musk made headlines by calling for the “elimination" of EVMs. “We should eliminate electronic voting machines. The risk of being hacked by humans or AI, while small, is still too high," he said on X. Responding to the remark, former Union Minister Rajeev Chandrasekhar called Musk’s concerns a “huge sweeping generalisation" and said Indian EVMs are custom-designed, secure and isolated from any network or media with no connectivity. “This is a huge sweeping generalization statement that implies no one can build secure digital hardware. Wrong. Elon Musk’s view may apply to the US and other places – where they use regular compute platforms to build Internet-connected Voting machines," Chandrasekhar wrote. This is a huge sweeping generalization statement that implies no one can build secure digital hardware. Wrong. @elonmusk ‘s view may apply to US n other places – where they use regular compute platforms to build Internet connected Voting machines.But Indian EVMs are custom… https://t.co/GiaCqU1n7O — Rajeev Chandrasekhar 🇮🇳 (@RajeevRC_X) June 16, 2024 Meanwhile, Rahul Gandhi also reacted to Musk’s tweet, calling EVM the ‘black box’ that nobody is allowed to scrutinise. “Serious concerns are being raised about transparency in our electoral process. Democracy ends up becoming a sham and prone to fraud when institutions lack accountability," he added. The opposition parties have been raising concerns over EVMs for a long time and alleged EVM tampering in the Assembly elections in Haryana and Maharashtra last year. EVMs in India are a “black box," and nobody is allowed to scrutinize them.Serious concerns are being raised about transparency in our electoral process. Democracy ends up becoming a sham and prone to fraud when institutions lack accountability. https://t.co/nysn5S8DCF pic.twitter.com/7sdTWJXOAb — Rahul Gandhi (@RahulGandhi) June 16, 2024 Elon Musk’s Remark On Vote-Counting In India Weeks after the US presidential election went in favour of President-elect Donald Trump, Musk praised the Indian electoral system and its ability to deliver the outcome of an election in a day, while also taking a jibe at the process in the US where the poll is yet to be called in California. “India counted 640 million votes in 1 day. California is still counting votes," Musk said in November, while responding to an X post that shared a news article with the Headline “How India Counted 640 Million Votes in a Day". India counted 640 million votes in 1...

title: Electoral Roll To EVM: Poll Panel Rebuts Charges Against Voting System Ahead Of Delhi Polls
summary: Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar on Tuesday addressed the concerns raised by opposition parties on various aspects of voting systems during elections.
full_content: Electoral Roll To EVM: Poll Panel Rebuts Charges Against Voting System Ahead Of Delhi Polls Curated By : Ronit Singh News18.com Last Updated: January 07, 2025, 15:21 IST Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar on Tuesday addressed the concerns raised by opposition parties on various aspects of voting systems during elections. reset Follow us on Google News CEC Rajiv Kumar | PTI Image Ahead of the Delhi Assembly Elections 2025, Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar on Tuesday addressed the concerns raised by various parties on several aspects of voting systems during elections. Dismissing the claims of electoral roll manipulation, tampering with electronic voting machines, and irregularities in voter turnout numbers, the poll panel chief said, “Aaj Jawab Toh Banta Hai." related stories CEC Rajiv Kumar also announced the poll schedule for Delhi Assembly elections. The national capital will vote in a single phase on February 5, with counting of votes on February 8, according to the Election Commission. “There were certain kinds of concerns that were raised (by political parties). It was said that wrongful addition and deletion were made in electoral rolls. It was also said that certain groups are targeted and their names are deleted. Even after giving a reply about EVM – it was said that EVM can be manipulated," CEC Rajiv Kumar said. #WATCH | Delhi | Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar says, “Indian voters are extremely aware… Stories are going around regarding electoral rolls, even now. Almost 70 steps are there…in which political parties and candidates remain with us… All the claims and objections that… pic.twitter.com/eTiea0tCS3 — ANI (@ANI) January 7, 2025 The CEC maintained that there is no scope for electoral manipulations, as every step of the election process is conducted in close coordination with political parties and their agents and with complete transparency. On the allegations of electoral roll manipulation, which were raised by both the AAP and BJP in Delhi, the commission highlighted the extensive procedure of preparing the rolls involving 70 steps and said each stage is carried out in consultation with political parties. “There are 70 steps involved in the process of preparing the voters’ list until the election. Political parties or candidates continuously engage with these steps, and regular meetings are held at various levels," he said. EC Rebuts EVM Charges Responding to the allegations of EVM tampering, CEC Rajiv Kumar cited a Supreme Court ruling to say that voting machines can never be rigged under any circumstances and called it a “Foolproof" device. “There is no question of introducing a virus or bug in the EVM. There is no question of invalid votes in the EVM. No rigging is possible. High Courts and the Supreme Court are continuously saying this in different judgments. What else can be said? EVMs are foolproof devices for counting. Allegations of tempering are baseless," he said. After the recently held Maharashtra elections, concerns were raised by opposition parties over the surge in voter turnout post-evening. The poll panel responded to the concerns, saying that changes in voter turnout occur after the polling ends at 5 pm due to delayed reports from some booths. top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all “It is impossible to alter voter turnout. Some polling parties report at midnight or the next day. Form 17C is matched before counting. There is nothing that the Voter Turnout Report (VTR) doesn’t explain. It provides a full explanation," he said. tags : delhi elections election commission Location : Delhi, India First Published: January 07, 2025, 14:36 IST News elections Electoral Roll To EVM: Poll Panel Rebuts Charges Against Voting System Ahead Of Delhi Polls Read More
